skill.name: designing-apis
skill.description: Designs REST and GraphQL APIs including endpoints, error handling, versioning, and documentation. Use when creating new APIs, designing endpoints, reviewing API contracts, or when asked about REST, GraphQL, or API patterns.
skill.summary: Designs REST and GraphQL APIs including endpoints, error handling, versioning, and documentation. Us...
skill.author: CloudAI-X

security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation and guidance skill containing only markdown files with API design best practices. No executable code, no file system access, no network calls, and no external command execution. The skill provides templates and patterns for designing REST and GraphQL APIs.

content.value_statement: API design mistakes are expensive to fix after implementation. This skill provides proven patterns for endpoints, error handling, versioning, and documentation so you can design clean, maintainable APIs from the start.
actual_capabilities: Design REST API endpoints with proper URL structure and HTTP methods
Define consistent response formats with pagination and error handling
Create GraphQL schema definitions with queries, mutations, and connections
Write OpenAPI 3.0 specification templates for documentation
Implement API versioning strategies using URL paths or headers
Apply security patterns including authentication, rate limiting, and CORS
limitations: Does not generate working API code or server implementations
Does not validate existing APIs or test endpoints
Does not integrate with API gateways or documentation tools
Does not provide backend implementation guidance

use_cases.title: Design New APIs
use_cases.description: Create well-structured REST or GraphQL APIs following industry best practices and standards.

use_cases.title: Review API Contracts
use_cases.description: Validate API designs against checklist for consistency, security, and proper error handling.

use_cases.title: Document with OpenAPI
use_cases.description: Write complete OpenAPI 3.0 specifications for your APIs with examples and security schemes.

prompt_templates.title: Basic API Design
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a REST API for managing [resource]. Include endpoints for create, read, update, delete. Show URL structure, HTTP methods, and response formats.

prompt_templates.title: Error Handling
prompt_templates.prompt: Design error response format for a [REST/GraphQL] API. Include error codes, messages, and field-level validation details.

prompt_templates.title: API Versioning
prompt_templates.prompt: Design an API versioning strategy for [service]. Compare URL versioning versus header versioning. Show examples of both approaches.

prompt_templates.title: OpenAPI Spec
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a complete OpenAPI 3.0 specification for a [type] API. Include paths, components, schemas, security schemes, and example responses.

output_examples.input: Design a user management REST API with proper error handling and pagination
output: Endpoints: GET /users, POST /users, GET /users/:id, PUT /users/:id, DELETE /users/:id
Pagination: Use page and limit query params with meta object containing total, page, limit, totalPages
Error format: { error: { code: string, message: string, details: [{ field: string, message: string }] } }
Status codes: 200 OK, 201 Created, 204 No Content, 400 Bad Request, 401 Unauthorized, 403 Forbidden, 404 Not Found, 422 Unprocessable, 429 Too Many Requests, 500 Internal Error

best_practices: Use nouns not verbs in endpoint URLs and match HTTP methods to operations
Include requestId in all responses for debugging and audit trails
Implement consistent error formats with actionable details for developers
Add rate limiting headers (X-RateLimit-*) to help clients manage request quotas
anti_patterns: Using verbs in URLs like /getUsers or /createAccount instead of proper HTTP methods
Exposing sensitive data in URL parameters or query strings
Returning different error formats across different endpoints
Implementing API versioning through breaking changes instead of proper deprecation

faq.question: Does this skill generate code?
faq.answer: No. This skill provides design patterns, templates, and best practices for APIs. It does not generate working code implementations.

faq.question: What API styles are supported?
faq.answer: Both REST and GraphQL patterns are covered with complete examples for endpoints, schemas, queries, and mutations.

faq.question: Can I use this with OpenAPI tools?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill includes a complete OpenAPI 3.0 template compatible with swagger-cli, redocly, and other OpenAPI validators.

faq.question: Is this skill safe to use?
faq.answer: Yes. This is a read-only guidance skill with no file access, network calls, or code execution capabilities.

faq.question: Does it cover authentication?
faq.answer: Yes. JWT Bearer tokens, API keys, and security scheme definitions in OpenAPI specs are all documented.

faq.question: How is this different from code generation?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on API contract design and documentation. For implementation, combine with code generation skills.
